attributes.description: Olympic Destroyer is malware that was used by Sandworm Team against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems inoperable. The malware leverages various native Windows utilities and API calls to carry out its destructive tasks. Olympic Destroyer has worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network in order to maximize its destructive impact.

attributes.name: Exaramel for Windows
attributes.description: Exaramel for Windows is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under Exaramel for Linux.

attributes.name: Invoke-PSImage
attributes.description: Invoke-PSImage takes a PowerShell script and embeds the bytes of the script into the pixels of a PNG image. It generates a one liner for executing either from a file of from the web. Example of usage is embedding the PowerShell code from the Invoke-Mimikatz module and embed it into an image file. By calling the image file from a macro for example, the macro will download the picture and execute the PowerShell code, which in this case will dump the passwords.

attributes.name: BlackEnergy
attributes.description: BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3.

attributes.name: CHEMISTGAMES
attributes.description: CHEMISTGAMES is a modular backdoor that has been deployed by Sandworm Team.

techniques.T1475: Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

attributes.name: Industroyer
attributes.description: Industroyer is a sophisticated piece of malware designed to cause an Impact to the working processes of Industrial Control Systems (ICS), specifically ICSs used in electrical substations. Industroyer was alleged to be used in the attacks on the Ukrainian power grid in December 2016.)

attributes.name: Killdisk
attributes.description: In 2015 the BlackEnergy malware contained a component called KillDisk. KillDisk's main functionality is to overwrite files with random data, rendering the OS unbootable.

attributes.name: Poseidon Group
attributes.description: Poseidon Group is a Portuguese-speaking threat group that has been active since at least 2005. The group has a history of using information exfiltrated from victims to blackmail victim companies into contracting the Poseidon Group as a security firm.

attributes.name: Lazarus Group
attributes.description:
Lazarus Group is a threat group that has been attributed to the North Korean government. The group has been active since at least 2009 and was reportedly responsible for the November 2014 destructive wiper attack against Sony Pictures Entertainment as part of a campaign named Operation Blockbuster by Novetta. Malware used by Lazarus Group correlates to other reported campaigns, including Operation Flame, Operation 1Mission, Operation Troy, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain.  In late 2017, Lazarus Group used KillDisk, a disk-wiping tool, in an attack against an online casino based in Central America. 

North Korean group definitions are known to have significant overlap, and the name Lazarus Group is known to encompass a broad range of activity. Some organizations use the name Lazarus Group to refer to any activity attributed to North Korea. Some organizations track North Korean clusters or groups such as Bluenoroff, APT37, and APT38 separately, while other organizations may track some activity associated with those group names by the name Lazarus Group.

attributes.name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
attributes.description: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON is a Remote Access Tool (RAT) used by Lazarus Group that was first identified in August 2020. It is a reconnaissance tool--with keylogging and screen capture functionality--used for information gathering on compromised systems.

attributes.name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
attributes.description: TAINTEDSCRIBE is a fully-featured beaconing implant integrated with command modules used by Lazarus Group. It was first reported in May 2020.

attributes.name: AppleJeus
attributes.description: AppleJeus is a family of downloaders initially discovered in 2018 embedded within trojanized cryptocurrency applications. AppleJeus has been used by Lazarus Group, targeting companies in the energy, finance, government, industry, technology, and telecommunications sectors, and several countries including the United States, United Kingdom, South Korea, Australia, Brazil, New Zealand, and Russia. AppleJeus has been used to distribute the FALLCHILL RAT.

attributes.name: Dtrack
attributes.description: Dtrack is spyware that was discovered in 2019 and has been used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant. Dtrack shares similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign, which was attributed to Lazarus Group.

attributes.name: BLINDINGCAN
attributes.description: BLINDINGCAN is a remote access Trojan that has been used by the North Korean government since at least early 2020 in cyber operations against defense, engineering, and government organizations in Western Europe and the US.

attributes.name: Cryptoistic
attributes.description: Cryptoistic is a backdoor, written in Swift, that has been used by Lazarus Group.

attributes.name: Dacls
attributes.description: Dacls is a multi-platform remote access tool used by Lazarus Group since at least December 2019.

attributes.name: HotCroissant
attributes.description: HotCroissant is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA. HotCroissant shares numerous code similarities with Rifdoor.

attributes.name: HOPLIGHT
attributes.description: HOPLIGHT is a backdoor Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government.

attributes.name: WannaCry
attributes.description: WannaCry is ransomware that was first seen in a global attack during May 2017, which affected more than 150 countries. It contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue.

techniques.T1222.001: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification

attributes.name: RawDisk
attributes.description: RawDisk is a legitimate commercial driver from the EldoS Corporation that is used for interacting with files, disks, and partitions. The driver allows for direct modification of data on a local computer's hard drive. In some cases, the tool can enact these raw disk modifications from user-mode processes, circumventing Windows operating system security features.

attributes.name: AuditCred
attributes.description: AuditCred is a malicious DLL that has been used by Lazarus Group during their 2018 attacks.

attributes.name: BADCALL
attributes.description: BADCALL is a Trojan malware variant used by the group Lazarus Group.

attributes.name: HARDRAIN
attributes.description: HARDRAIN is a Trojan malware variant reportedly used by the North Korean government.

attributes.name: RATANKBA
attributes.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group. RATANKBA has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. RATANKBA has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines.

attributes.name: Bankshot
attributes.description: Bankshot is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first reported by the Department of Homeland Security in December of 2017. In 2018, Lazarus Group used the Bankshot implant in attacks against the Turkish financial sector.

attributes.name: KEYMARBLE
attributes.description: KEYMARBLE is a Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government.

attributes.name: Proxysvc
attributes.description: Proxysvc is a malicious DLL used by Lazarus Group in a campaign known as Operation GhostSecret. It has appeared to be operating undetected since 2017 and was mostly observed in higher education organizations. The goal of Proxysvc is to deliver additional payloads to the target and to maintain control for the attacker. It is in the form of a DLL that can also be executed as a standalone process.

attributes.name: TYPEFRAME
attributes.description: TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool that has been used by Lazarus Group.

attributes.name: Volgmer
attributes.description: Volgmer is a backdoor Trojan designed to provide covert access to a compromised system. It has been used since at least 2013 to target the government, financial, automotive, and media industries. Its primary delivery mechanism is suspected to be spearphishing.

attributes.name: FALLCHILL
attributes.description: FALLCHILL is a RAT that has been used by Lazarus Group since at least 2016 to target the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance industries. It is usually dropped by other Lazarus Group malware or delivered when a victim unknowingly visits a compromised website.

attributes.name: Dust Storm
attributes.description: Dust Storm is a threat group that has targeted multiple industries in Japan, South Korea, the United States, Europe, and several Southeast Asian countries.

attributes.name: ZLib
attributes.description: ZLib is a full-featured backdoor that was used as a second-stage implant by Dust Storm from 2014 to 2015. It is malware and should not be confused with the compression library from which its name is derived.

attributes.name: S-Type
attributes.description: S-Type is a backdoor that was used by Dust Storm from 2013 to 2014.

attributes.name: Mis-Type
attributes.description: Mis-Type is a backdoor hybrid that was used by Dust Storm in 2012.

attributes.name: Misdat
attributes.description: Misdat is a backdoor that was used by Dust Storm from 2010 to 2011.

attributes.name: Lotus Blossom
attributes.description: Lotus Blossom is a threat group that has targeted government and military organizations in Southeast Asia.

attributes.name: Emissary
attributes.description: Emissary is a Trojan that has been used by Lotus Blossom. It shares code with Elise, with both Trojans being part of a malware group referred to as LStudio.

attributes.name: Elise
attributes.description:
Elise is a custom backdoor Trojan that appears to be used exclusively by Lotus Blossom. It is part of a larger group of
tools referred to as LStudio, ST Group, and APT0LSTU.

attributes.name: Scarlet Mimic
attributes.description: Scarlet Mimic is a threat group that has targeted minority rights activists. This group has not been directly linked to a government source, but the group's motivations appear to overlap with those of the Chinese government. While there is some overlap between IP addresses used by Scarlet Mimic and Putter Panda, it has not been concluded that the groups are the same.

attributes.name: MobileOrder
attributes.description: MobileOrder is a Trojan intended to compromise Android mobile devices. It has been used by Scarlet Mimic.

attributes.name: Psylo
attributes.description: Psylo is a shellcode-based Trojan that has been used by Scarlet Mimic. It has similar characteristics as FakeM.

attributes.name: CallMe
attributes.description: CallMe is a Trojan designed to run on Apple OSX. It is based on a publicly available tool called Tiny SHell.

attributes.name: FakeM
attributes.description: FakeM is a shellcode-based Windows backdoor that has been used by Scarlet Mimic.

attributes.name: Threat Group-1314
attributes.description: Threat Group-1314 is an unattributed threat group that has used compromised credentials to log into a victim's remote access infrastructure.

attributes.name: Threat Group-3390
attributes.description: Threat Group-3390 is a Chinese threat group that has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims.  The group has been active since at least 2010 and has targeted organizations in the aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, and manufacturing sectors.

attributes.name: HyperBro
attributes.description: HyperBro is a custom in-memory backdoor used by Threat Group-3390.

attributes.name: OwaAuth
attributes.description: OwaAuth is a Web shell and credential stealer deployed to Microsoft Exchange servers that appears to be exclusively used by Threat Group-3390.

attributes.name: HTTPBrowser
attributes.description: HTTPBrowser is malware that has been used by several threat groups.   It is believed to be of Chinese origin.

attributes.name: APT18
attributes.description: APT18 is a threat group that has operated since at least 2009 and has targeted a range of industries, including technology, manufacturing, human rights groups, government, and medical.

attributes.name: Pisloader
attributes.description: Pisloader is a malware family that is notable due to its use of DNS as a C2 protocol as well as its use of anti-analysis tactics. It has been used by APT18 and is similar to another malware family, HTTPBrowser, that has been used by the group.

attributes.name: hcdLoader
attributes.description: hcdLoader is a remote access tool (RAT) that has been used by APT18.

attributes.name: APT17
attributes.description: APT17 is a China-based threat group that has conducted network intrusions against U.S. government entities, the defense industry, law firms, information technology companies, mining companies, and non-government organizations.

techniques.T1342: Develop social network persona digital footprint

attributes.name: Putter Panda
attributes.description: Putter Panda is a Chinese threat group that has been attributed to Unit 61486 of the 12th Bureau of the PLA’s 3rd General Staff Department (GSD).

attributes.name: httpclient
attributes.description: httpclient is malware used by Putter Panda. It is a simple tool that provides a limited range of functionality, suggesting it is likely used as a second-stage or supplementary/backup tool.

attributes.name: pngdowner
attributes.description:
pngdowner is malware used by Putter Panda. It is a simple tool with limited functionality and no persistence mechanism, suggesting it is used only as a simple "download-and-
execute" utility.

attributes.name: 3PARA RAT
attributes.description: 3PARA RAT is a remote access tool (RAT) programmed in C++ that has been used by Putter Panda.

attributes.name: 4H RAT
attributes.description: 4H RAT is malware that has been used by Putter Panda since at least 2007.

attributes.name: APT16
attributes.description: APT16 is a China-based threat group that has launched spearphishing campaigns targeting Japanese and Taiwanese organizations.

techniques.T1334: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery

attributes.name: ELMER
attributes.description: ELMER is a non-persistent, proxy-aware HTTP backdoor written in Delphi that has been used by APT16.

attributes.name: APT3
attributes.description:
APT3 is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.   This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.   As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong. 

MITRE has also developed an APT3 Adversary Emulation Plan.

attributes.name: OSInfo
attributes.description: OSInfo is a custom tool used by APT3 to do internal discovery on a victim's computer and network.

attributes.name: RemoteCMD
attributes.description: RemoteCMD is a custom tool used by APT3 to execute commands on a remote system similar to SysInternal's PSEXEC functionality.

attributes.name: SHOTPUT
attributes.description: SHOTPUT is a custom backdoor used by APT3.

attributes.name: Molerats
attributes.description: Molerats is an Arabic-speaking, politically-motivated threat group that has been operating since 2012. The group's victims have primarily been in the Middle East, Europe, and the United States.

attributes.name: MoleNet
attributes.description: MoleNet is a downloader tool with backdoor capabilities that has been observed in use since at least 2019.

attributes.name: DropBook
attributes.description: DropBook is a Python-based backdoor compiled with PyInstaller.

attributes.name: SharpStage
attributes.description: SharpStage is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.

attributes.name: Spark
attributes.description: Spark is a Windows backdoor and has been in use since as early as 2017.

attributes.name: DustySky
attributes.description: DustySky is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by Molerats since May 2015.

attributes.name: Equation
attributes.description: Equation is a sophisticated threat group that employs multiple remote access tools. The group is known to use zero-day exploits and has developed the capability to overwrite the firmware of hard disk drives.

attributes.name: Naikon
attributes.description: Naikon is a threat group that has focused on targets around the South China Sea. The group has been attributed to the Chinese People’s Liberation Army’s (PLA) Chengdu Military Region Second Technical Reconnaissance Bureau(Military Unit Cover Designator 78020). While Naikon shares some characteristics with APT30, the two groups do not appear to be exact matches.

attributes.name: Aria-body
attributes.description: Aria-body is a custom backdoor that has been used by Naikon.

attributes.name: HDoor
attributes.description: HDoor is malware that has been customized and used by the Naikon group.

attributes.name: Sys10
attributes.description: Sys10 is a backdoor that was used throughout 2013 by Naikon.

attributes.name: WinMM
attributes.description: WinMM is a full-featured, simple backdoor used by Naikon.

attributes.name: SslMM
attributes.description: SslMM is a full-featured backdoor used by Naikon that has multiple variants.

attributes.name: RARSTONE
attributes.description: RARSTONE is malware used by the Naikon group that has some characteristics similar to PlugX.

attributes.name: admin@338
attributes.description: admin@338 is a China-based cyber threat group. It has previously used newsworthy events as lures to deliver malware and has primarily targeted organizations involved in financial, economic, and trade policy, typically using publicly available RATs such as PoisonIvy, as well as some non-public backdoors.

attributes.name: BUBBLEWRAP
attributes.description: BUBBLEWRAP is a full-featured, second-stage backdoor used by the admin@338 group. It is set to run when the system boots and includes functionality to check, upload, and register plug-ins that can further enhance its capabilities.

attributes.name: LOWBALL
attributes.description: LOWBALL is malware used by admin@338. It was used in August 2015 in email messages targeting Hong Kong-based media organizations.

attributes.name: DragonOK
attributes.description: DragonOK is a threat group that has targeted Japanese organizations with phishing emails. Due to overlapping TTPs, including similar custom tools, DragonOK is thought to have a direct or indirect relationship with the threat group Moafee.  It is known to use a variety of malware, including Sysget/HelloBridge, PlugX, PoisonIvy, FormerFirstRat, NFlog, and NewCT.

attributes.name: APT29
attributes.description:
APT29 is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. APT29 reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the SolarWinds supply chain compromise cyber operation to the SVR; public statements included citations to APT29, Cozy Bear, and The Dukes. Victims of this campaign included government, consulting, technology, telecom, and other organizations in North America, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. Industry reporting referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, and Dark Halo.

techniques.T1048.002: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol

attributes.name: GoldFinder
attributes.description: GoldFinder is a custom HTTP tracer tool written in Go that logs the route a packet takes between a compromised network and a C2 server. It can be used to inform  threat actors of potential points of discovery or logging of their actions, including C2 related to other malware. GoldFinder was discovered in early 2021 during an investigation into the SolarWinds cyber intrusion by APT29.

attributes.name: Sibot
attributes.description: Sibot is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three Sibot variants in early 2021 during its investigation of APT29 and the SolarWinds cyber intrusion campaign.

attributes.name: GoldMax
attributes.description: GoldMax is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go that was used by APT29 and discovered in early 2021 during the investigation into breaches related to the SolarWinds intrusion. GoldMax uses multiple defense evasion techniques, including avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic.

attributes.name: Raindrop
attributes.description: Raindrop is a loader used by APT29 that was discovered on some victim machines during investigations related to the 2020 SolarWinds cyber intrusion. It was discovered in January 2021 and was likely used since at least May 2020.

attributes.name: SUNSPOT
attributes.description: SUNSPOT is an implant that injected the SUNBURST backdoor into the SolarWinds Orion software update framework. It was used by APT29 since at least February 2020.

attributes.name: TEARDROP
attributes.description: TEARDROP is a memory-only dropper that was discovered on some victim machines during investigations related to the 2020 SolarWinds cyber intrusion. It was likely used by APT29 since at least May 2020.

attributes.name: SUNBURST
attributes.description: SUNBURST is a trojanized DLL designed to fit within the SolarWinds Orion software update framework. It was used by APT29 since at least February 2020.

attributes.name: SoreFang
attributes.description: SoreFang is first stage downloader used by APT29 for exfiltration and to load other malware.

attributes.name: WellMail
attributes.description: WellMail is a lightweight malware written in Golang used by APT29, similar in design and structure to WellMess.

attributes.name: WellMess
attributes.description: WellMess is lightweight malware family with variants written in .NET and Golang that has been in use since at least 2018 by APT29.

attributes.name: RegDuke
attributes.description: RegDuke is a first stage implant written in .NET and used by APT29 since at least 2017. RegDuke has been used to control a compromised machine when control of other implants on the machine was lost.

attributes.name: PolyglotDuke
attributes.description: PolyglotDuke is a downloader that has been used by APT29 since at least 2013. PolyglotDuke has been used to drop MiniDuke.

attributes.name: Tor
attributes.description: Tor is a software suite and network that provides increased anonymity on the Internet. It creates a multi-hop proxy network and utilizes multilayer encryption to protect both the message and routing information. Tor utilizes "Onion Routing," in which messages are encrypted with multiple layers of encryption; at each step in the proxy network, the topmost layer is decrypted and the contents forwarded on to the next node until it reaches its destination.

attributes.name: meek
attributes.description: meek is an open-source Tor plugin that tunnels Tor traffic through HTTPS connections.

attributes.name: POSHSPY
attributes.description: POSHSPY is a backdoor that has been used by APT29 since at least 2015. It appears to be used as a secondary backdoor used if the actors lost access to their primary backdoors.

attributes.name: PowerDuke
attributes.description: PowerDuke is a backdoor that was used by APT29 in 2016. It has primarily been delivered through Microsoft Word or Excel attachments containing malicious macros.

attributes.name: CloudDuke
attributes.description: CloudDuke is malware that was used by APT29 in 2015.

attributes.name: SeaDuke
attributes.description: SeaDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2014 to 2015. It was used primarily as a secondary backdoor for victims that were already compromised with CozyCar.

attributes.name: OnionDuke
attributes.description: OnionDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2013 to 2015.

attributes.name: MiniDuke
attributes.description: MiniDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015. The MiniDuke toolset consists of multiple downloader and backdoor components. The loader has been used with other MiniDuke components as well as in conjunction with CosmicDuke and PinchDuke.

attributes.name: CosmicDuke
attributes.description: CosmicDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015.

attributes.name: GeminiDuke
attributes.description: GeminiDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2009 to 2012.

attributes.name: PinchDuke
attributes.description: PinchDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2008 to 2010.

attributes.name: CozyCar
attributes.description: CozyCar is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality.

attributes.name: HAMMERTOSS
attributes.description: HAMMERTOSS is a backdoor that was used by APT29 in 2015.

attributes.name: Taidoor
attributes.description: Taidoor is a threat group that has operated since at least 2009 and has primarily targeted the Taiwanese government.

attributes.name: Night Dragon
attributes.description: Night Dragon is a campaign name for activity involving a threat group that has conducted activity originating primarily in China.

techniques.T1307: Acquire and/or use 3rd party infrastructure services
techniques.T1330: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services

attributes.name: zwShell
attributes.description: zwShell is a remote access tool (RAT) written in Delphi that has been used by Night Dragon.

attributes.name: APT30
attributes.description: APT30 is a threat group suspected to be associated with the Chinese government. While Naikon shares some characteristics with APT30, the two groups do not appear to be exact matches.

attributes.name: FLASHFLOOD
attributes.description: FLASHFLOOD is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps.

attributes.name: SPACESHIP
attributes.description: SPACESHIP is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps.

attributes.name: NETEAGLE
attributes.description: NETEAGLE is a backdoor developed by APT30 with compile dates as early as 2008. It has two main variants known as “Scout” and “Norton.”

attributes.name: BACKSPACE
attributes.description: BACKSPACE is a backdoor used by APT30 that dates back to at least 2005.

attributes.name: SHIPSHAPE
attributes.description: SHIPSHAPE is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps.

attributes.name: Darkhotel
attributes.description: Darkhotel is a suspected South Korean threat group that has targeted victims primarily in East Asia since at least 2004. The group's name is based on cyber espionage operations conducted via hotel Internet networks against traveling executives and other select guests. Darkhotel has also conducted spearphishing campaigns and infected victims through peer-to-peer and file sharing networks.

attributes.name: PittyTiger
attributes.description: PittyTiger is a threat group believed to operate out of China that uses multiple different types of malware to maintain command and control.

attributes.name: Lurid
attributes.description: Lurid is a malware family that has been used by several groups, including PittyTiger, in targeted attacks as far back as 2006.

attributes.name: Turla
attributes.description: Turla is a Russian-based threat group that has infected victims in over 45 countries, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies since 2004. Heightened activity was seen in mid-2015. Turla is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns and leveraging in-house tools and malware. Turla’s espionage platform is mainly used against Windows machines, but has also been seen used against macOS and Linux machines.

attributes.name: Penquin
attributes.description: Penquin is a remote access trojan (RAT) with multiple versions used by Turla to target Linux systems since at least 2014.

techniques.T1222.002: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification

attributes.name: IronNetInjector
attributes.description: IronNetInjector is a Turla toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including ComRAT.

attributes.name: Crutch
attributes.description: Crutch is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by Turla since at least 2015.

attributes.name: HyperStack
attributes.description: HyperStack is a RPC-based backdoor used by Turla since at least 2018. HyperStack has similarities to other backdoors used by Turla including Carbon.

attributes.name: LightNeuron
attributes.description: LightNeuron is a sophisticated backdoor that has targeted Microsoft Exchange servers since at least 2014. LightNeuron has been used by Turla to target diplomatic and foreign affairs-related organizations. The presence of certain strings in the malware suggests a Linux variant of LightNeuron exists.

attributes.name: PowerStallion
attributes.description: PowerStallion is a lightweight PowerShell backdoor used by Turla, possibly as a recovery access tool to install other backdoors.

attributes.name: Carbon
attributes.description: Carbon is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework that can be used to steal sensitive information from victims. Carbon has been selectively used by Turla to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.

attributes.name: Mosquito
attributes.description: Mosquito is a Win32 backdoor that has been used by Turla. Mosquito is made up of three parts: the installer, the launcher, and the backdoor. The main backdoor is called CommanderDLL and is launched by the loader program.

attributes.name: Kazuar
attributes.description: Kazuar is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework.

attributes.name: Gazer
attributes.description: Gazer is a backdoor used by Turla since at least 2016.

attributes.name: ComRAT
attributes.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of Agent.btz and used by Turla. The first version of ComRAT was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.

attributes.name: nbtstat
attributes.description: nbtstat is a utility used to troubleshoot NetBIOS name resolution.

attributes.name: Epic
attributes.description: Epic is a backdoor that has been used by Turla.

attributes.name: Uroburos
attributes.description: Uroburos is a rootkit used by Turla.

attributes.name: Deep Panda
attributes.description: Deep Panda is a suspected Chinese threat group known to target many industries, including government, defense, financial, and telecommunications.  The intrusion into healthcare company Anthem has been attributed to Deep Panda.  This group is also known as Shell Crew, WebMasters, KungFu Kittens, and PinkPanther.  Deep Panda also appears to be known as Black Vine based on the attribution of both group names to the Anthem intrusion.  Some analysts track Deep Panda and APT19 as the same group, but it is unclear from open source information if the groups are the same.

attributes.name: StreamEx
attributes.description: StreamEx is a malware family that has been used by Deep Panda since at least 2015. In 2016, it was distributed via legitimate compromised Korean websites.

attributes.name: Mivast
attributes.description: Mivast is a backdoor that has been used by Deep Panda. It was reportedly used in the Anthem breach.

attributes.name: Sakula
attributes.description: Sakula is a remote access tool (RAT) that first surfaced in 2012 and was used in intrusions throughout 2015.

attributes.name: Carbanak
attributes.description: Carbanak is a threat group that mainly targets banks. It also refers to malware of the same name (Carbanak). It is sometimes referred to as FIN7, but these appear to be two groups using the same Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately.

attributes.name: APT28
attributes.description:
APT28 is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165. This group has been active since at least 2004.          

APT28 reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.  In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with APT28 for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations. Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as Sandworm Team.

attributes.name: Drovorub
attributes.description: Drovorub is a Linux malware toolset comprised of an agent, client, server, and kernel modules, that has been used by APT28.

attributes.name: Fysbis
attributes.description: Fysbis is a Linux-based backdoor used by APT28 that dates back to at least 2014.

attributes.name: LoJax
attributes.description: LoJax is a UEFI rootkit used by APT28 to persist remote access software on targeted systems.

attributes.name: Cannon
attributes.description: Cannon is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018.

attributes.name: Zebrocy
attributes.description: Zebrocy is a Trojan that has been used by APT28 since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang.

attributes.name: DealersChoice
attributes.description: DealersChoice is a Flash exploitation framework used by APT28.

attributes.name: Forfiles
attributes.description: Forfiles is a Windows utility commonly used in batch jobs to execute commands on one or more selected files or directories (ex: list all directories in a drive, read the first line of all files created yesterday, etc.). Forfiles can be executed from either the command line, Run window, or batch files/scripts.

attributes.name: Responder
attributes.description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication.

attributes.name: XAgentOSX
attributes.description: XAgentOSX is a trojan that has been used by APT28  on OS X and appears to be a port of their standard CHOPSTICK or XAgent trojan.

attributes.name: Komplex
attributes.description: Komplex is a backdoor that has been used by APT28 on OS X and appears to be developed in a similar manner to XAgentOSX  .

attributes.name: OLDBAIT
attributes.description: OLDBAIT is a credential harvester used by APT28.

attributes.name: CORESHELL
attributes.description: CORESHELL is a downloader used by APT28. The older versions of this malware are known as SOURFACE and newer versions as CORESHELL.

attributes.name: USBStealer
attributes.description: USBStealer is malware that has used by APT28 since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with ADVSTORESHELL.

attributes.name: HIDEDRV
attributes.description: HIDEDRV is a rootkit used by APT28. It has been deployed along with Downdelph to execute and hide that malware.

attributes.name: Downdelph
attributes.description: Downdelph is a first-stage downloader written in Delphi that has been used by APT28 in rare instances between 2013 and 2015.

attributes.name: XTunnel
attributes.description: XTunnel a VPN-like network proxy tool that can relay traffic between a C2 server and a victim. It was first seen in May 2013 and reportedly used by APT28 during the compromise of the Democratic National Committee.

attributes.name: ADVSTORESHELL
attributes.description: ADVSTORESHELL is a spying backdoor that has been used by APT28 from at least 2012 to 2016. It is generally used for long-term espionage and is deployed on targets deemed interesting after a reconnaissance phase.

attributes.name: JHUHUGIT
attributes.description: JHUHUGIT is malware used by APT28. It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware.

attributes.name: CHOPSTICK
attributes.description: CHOPSTICK is a malware family of modular backdoors used by APT28. It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants.     It is tracked separately from the X-Agent for Android.

attributes.name: X-Agent for Android
attributes.description: X-Agent for Android is Android malware that was placed in a repackaged version of a Ukrainian artillery targeting application. The malware reportedly retrieved general location data on where the victim device was used, and therefore could likely indicate the potential location of Ukrainian artillery.  Is it tracked separately from the CHOPSTICK.

attributes.name: APT1
attributes.description: APT1 is a Chinese threat group that has been attributed to the 2nd Bureau of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) General Staff Department’s (GSD) 3rd Department, commonly known by its Military Unit Cover Designator (MUCD) as Unit 61398.

techniques.T1330: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services
techniques.T1312: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery

attributes.name: Seasalt
attributes.description: Seasalt is malware that has been linked to APT1's 2010 operations. It shares some code similarities with OceanSalt.

attributes.name: xCmd
attributes.description: xCmd is an open source tool that is similar to PsExec and allows the user to execute applications on remote systems.

attributes.name: Pass-The-Hash Toolkit
attributes.description: Pass-The-Hash Toolkit is a toolkit that allows an adversary to "pass" a password hash (without knowing the original password) to log in to systems.

attributes.name: Lslsass
attributes.description: Lslsass is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process.

attributes.name: Cachedump
attributes.description: Cachedump is a publicly-available tool that program extracts cached password hashes from a system’s registry.

attributes.name: WEBC2
attributes.description: WEBC2 is a family of backdoor malware used by APT1 as early as July 2006. WEBC2 backdoors are designed to retrieve a webpage, with commands hidden in HTML comments or special tags, from a predetermined C2 server.

attributes.name: GLOOXMAIL
attributes.description: GLOOXMAIL is malware used by APT1 that mimics legitimate Jabber/XMPP traffic.

attributes.name: CALENDAR
attributes.description: CALENDAR is malware used by APT1 that mimics legitimate Gmail Calendar traffic.

attributes.name: BISCUIT
attributes.description: BISCUIT is a backdoor that has been used by APT1 since as early as 2007.

attributes.name: APT12
attributes.description: APT12 is a threat group that has been attributed to China. The group has targeted a variety of victims including but not limited to media outlets, high-tech companies, and multiple governments.

attributes.name: Ixeshe
attributes.description: Ixeshe is a malware family that has been used since at least 2009 against targets in East Asia.

attributes.name: RIPTIDE
attributes.description: RIPTIDE is a proxy-aware backdoor used by APT12.

attributes.name: Ke3chang
attributes.description: Ke3chang is a threat group attributed to actors operating out of China. Ke3chang has targeted several industries, including oil, government, military, and more.

attributes.name: Okrum
attributes.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to Ke3chang.

attributes.name: MirageFox
attributes.description: MirageFox is a remote access tool used against Windows systems. It appears to be an upgraded version of a tool known as Mirage, which is a RAT believed to originate in 2012.

attributes.name: spwebmember
attributes.description: spwebmember is a Microsoft SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool written in .NET.

attributes.name: Cleaver
attributes.description: Cleaver is a threat group that has been attributed to Iranian actors and is responsible for activity tracked as Operation Cleaver.  Strong circumstantial evidence suggests Cleaver is linked to Threat Group 2889 (TG-2889).

techniques.T1342: Develop social network persona digital footprint

attributes.name: Net Crawler
attributes.description: Net Crawler is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using PsExec to execute a copy of Net Crawler.

attributes.name: TinyZBot
attributes.description: TinyZBot is a bot written in C# that was developed by Cleaver.

attributes.name: Moafee
attributes.description: Moafee is a threat group that appears to operate from the Guandong Province of China. Due to overlapping TTPs, including similar custom tools, Moafee is thought to have a direct or indirect relationship with the threat group DragonOK.

attributes.name: Axiom
attributes.description: Axiom is a cyber espionage group suspected to be associated with the Chinese government. It is responsible for the Operation SMN campaign.  Though both this group and Winnti Group use the malware Winnti for Windows, the two groups appear to be distinct based on differences in reporting on the groups' TTPs and targeting.

attributes.name: Hikit
attributes.description: Hikit is malware that has been used by Axiom for late-stage persistence and exfiltration after the initial compromise.

attributes.name: Bouncing Golf
attributes.description: Bouncing Golf is a cyberespionage campaign targeting Middle Eastern countries.

techniques.T1476: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means

attributes.name: GolfSpy
attributes.description: GolfSpy is Android spyware deployed by the group Bouncing Golf.

techniques.T1476: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means

attributes.name: HEXANE
attributes.description: HEXANE is a threat group that has targeted ICS organization within the oil & gas, and telecommunications sectors. Many of the targeted organizations have been located in the Middle East including Kuwait. HEXANE's targeting of telecommunications has been speculated to be part of an effort to establish man-in-the-middle capabilities throughout the region. HEXANE's TTPs appear similar to APT33 and OilRig but due to differences in victims and tools it is tracked as a separate entity.

attributes.name: ALLANITE
attributes.description: ALLANITE is a suspected Russian cyber espionage group, that has primarily targeted the electric utility sector within the United States and United Kingdom. The group's tactics and techniques are reportedly similar to Dragonfly / Dragonfly 2.0, although ALLANITE’s technical capabilities have not exhibited disruptive or destructive abilities. It has been suggested that the group maintains a presence in ICS for the purpose of gaining understanding of processes and to maintain persistence.
